text: 3D Simulations of Oxygen Shell Burning with and without Magnetic Fields
School of Physics and Astronomy, 10 College Walk, Monash University, Clayton, VIC 3800, Australia
ARC Centre of Excellence for Gravitational Wave Discovery â€“ OzGrav
Accepted XXX. Received YYY; in original form ZZZ

We present a ï¬rst 3D magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) simulation of convective oxygen and neon shell burning in a non-rotating
18

star shortly before core collapse to study the generation of magnetic ï¬elds in supernova progenitors. We also run a purely
hydrodynamic control simulation to gauge the impact of the magnetic ï¬elds on the convective ï¬‚ow and on convective boundary
mixing. After about 17 convective turnover times, the magnetic ï¬eld is approaching saturation levels in the oxygen shell with
an average ï¬eld strength of
G, and does not reach kinetic equipartition. The ï¬eld remains dominated by small to medium
scales, and the dipole ï¬eld strength at the base of the oxygen shell is only 10

G. The angle-averaged diagonal components of the
Maxwell stress tensor mirror those of the Reynolds stress tensor, but are about one order of magnitude smaller. The shear ï¬‚ow
at the oxygen-neon shell interface creates relatively strong ï¬elds parallel to the convective boundary, which noticeably inhibit
the turbulent entrainment of neon into the oxygen shell. The reduced ingestion of neon lowers the nuclear energy generation rate
in the oxygen shell and thereby slightly slows down the convective ï¬‚ow. Aside from this indirect eï¬€ect, we ï¬nd that magnetic
ï¬elds do not appreciably alter the ï¬‚ow inside the oxygen shell. We discuss the implications of our results for the subsequent
core-collapse supernova and stress the need for longer simulations, resolution studies, and an investigation of non-ideal eï¬€ects
for a better understanding of magnetic ï¬elds in supernova progenitors.
stars: massive â€“ stars: magnetic ï¬elds â€“ stars:interiors â€“ MHD â€“ convection â€“ turbulence

Rigorous three-dimensional (3D) simulations of neutrino-driven
core-collapse supernovae have become highly successful in recent
years (e.g., Melson et al. 2015; Lentz et al. 2015; Takiwaki et al.
2014; Burrows et al. 2019), and have made clear headway in explain-
ing the properties of supernova explosions and the compact objects
born in these events (MÃ¼ller et al. 2017; MÃ¼ller et al. 2019; Burrows
et al. 2020; Powell & MÃ¼ller 2020; Bollig et al. 2020; MÃ¼ller 2020).
The latest 3D models are able to reproduce a range of explosion en-

erg (Bollig et al. 2020), and yield neutron star birth
masses, kicks, and spins largely compatible with the population of
observed young pulsars (MÃ¼ller et al. 2019; Burrows et al. 2020).

A number of ingredients have contributed, or have the potential
to contribute, to make modern neutrino-driven explosion models
more robust. Various microphysical eï¬€ects such as reduced neutrino
scattering opacities due to nucleon strangeness (Melson et al. 2015)
and nucleon correlations at high densities (Horowitz et al. 2017;
Bollig et al. 2017; Burrows et al. 2018), muonisation (Bollig et al.
2017), and large eï¬€ective nucleon masses (Yasin et al. 2020) can be
conducive to neutrino-driven shock revival.

In addition, a particularly important turning point has been the
advent of 3D

MÃ¼ller & Janka 2015; MÃ¼ller 2016; MÃ¼ller et al. 2017; MÃ¼ller 2020;
Bollig et al. 2020). In perturbation-aided explosions, the moderately
subsonic solenoidal velocity perturbation in active convective shells
at the pre-collapse stage with Mach numbers of order

1 (Collins
et al. 2018) are transformed into strong density and pressure pertur-
bations at the shock (MÃ¼ller & Janka 2015; Takahashi & Yamada
2014; Takahashi et al. 2016; Abdikamalov & Foglizzo 2020), and ef-
fectively strengthen the violent non-radial ï¬‚ow behind the shock that
develops due to convective instability (Herant et al. 1994; Burrows

et al. 1995; Janka & MÃ¼ller 1995, 1996) and the standing accretion
shock instability (Blondin et al. 2003; Foglizzo et al. 2007), thereby
supporting neutrino-driven shock revival.

The discovery of perturbation-aided explosions has greatly en-
hanced interest in multi-dimensional models of late convective burn-
ing stages in massive stars. Several studies have by now followed the
immediate pre-collapse phase of silicon and/or oxygen shell burning
to collapse in 3D (Couch et al. 2015; MÃ¼ller 2016; MÃ¼ller et al. 2016;
MÃ¼ller et al. 2019; Yoshida et al. 2019; Yadav et al. 2020; McNeill
& MÃ¼ller 2020; Yoshida et al. 2020). In addition, there has been a
long-standing strand of research since the 1990s (e.g., Bazan & Ar-
nett 1994; BazÃ¡n & Arnett 1997; Meakin & Arnett 2006, 2007b,a;
MÃ¼ller et al. 2016; Jones et al. 2017; Cristini et al. 2017, 2019) into
the detailed behaviour of stellar convection during advanced burning
stages with a view to the

impact of 3D eï¬€ects not captured
by spherically symmetric stellar evolution models based on mixing-
length theory (Biermann 1932; BÃ¶hm-Vitense 1958). The details of
convective boundary mixing by processes such as quasi-steady turbu-

& Arnett 2007b) or violent shell mergers (MocÃ¡k et al. 2018; Ya-
dav et al. 2020) have received particular attention for their potential
to alter the core structure of massive stars and hence aï¬€ect the dy-
namics and ï¬nal nucleosynthesis yields of the subsequent supernova
explosion.

Three-dimensional simulations of convection during advanced
burning stages have so far largely disregarded two important aspects
of real stars â€“ rotation and magnetic ï¬elds. The eï¬€ects of rotation
have been touched upon by the seminal work of Kuhlen et al. (2003),
but more recent studies (Arnett & Meakin 2010; Chatzopoulos et al.
2016) have been limited to axisymmetry (2D). Magnetohydrody-
namic (MHD) simulations of convection, while common and mature
in the context of the Sun (for a review see, e.g., Charbonneau 2014)
have yet to be performed for advanced burning stages of massive
stars.

Simulations of magnetoconvection during the late burning stages,
both in rotating and non-rotating stars, are a big desideratum for sev-
eral reasons. Even in slowly rotating massive stars, magnetic ï¬elds
may have a non-negligible impact on the dynamics of neutrino-driven
explosions (Obergaulinger et al. 2014; MÃ¼ller & Varma 2020), and

although eï¬ƒcient ï¬eld ampliï¬cation processes operate in the super-
nova core (Endeve et al. 2012; MÃ¼ller & Varma 2020), it stands to
reason that memory of the initial ï¬elds may not be lost entirely, es-
pecially for strong ï¬elds in the progenitor and early explosions. A
better understanding of the interplay between convection, rotation,
and magnetic ï¬elds in supernova progenitors is even more critical
for the magnetorotational explosion scenario (e.g., Burrows et al.
2007; Winteler et al. 2012; MÃ¶sta et al. 2014; MÃ¶sta et al. 2018;
Obergaulinger & Aloy 2020a,b; Kuroda et al. 2020; Aloy & Ober-
gaulinger 2020), which probably explains rare, unusually energetic
â€œhypernovaeâ€ with energies of up to

erg. Again, even though
the requisite strong magnetic ï¬elds may be generated after collapse by
ampliï¬cation processes like the magnetorotational insstability (Bal-
bus & Hawley 1991; Akiyama et al. 2003) or an

dynamo in the
proto-neutron star (Duncan & Thompson 1992; Thompson & Duncan
1993; Raynaud et al. 2020), a robust understanding of magnetic ï¬elds
during late burning is indispensable for reliable hypernova models on
several heads. For suï¬ƒciently strong seed ï¬elds in the progenitor, the
initial ï¬eld strengths and geometry could have a signiï¬cant impact
on the development of magnetorotational explosions after collapse
(Bugli et al. 2020; Aloy & Obergaulinger 2020). Furthermore, our
understanding of evolutionary pathways towards hypernova explo-
sions (Woosley & Heger 2006; Yoon & Langer 2005; Yoon et al.
2010; Cantiello et al. 2007; Aguilera-Dena et al. 2018, 2020) is in-

timately connected with the eï¬€ects of magnetic ï¬elds on angular
momentum transport in stellar interiors (Spruit 2002; Heger et al.
2005; Fuller et al. 2019; Takahashi & Langer 2020).

Beyond the impact of magnetic ï¬elds on the pre-supernova evo-
lution and the supernova itself, the interplay of convection, rotation,
and magnetic ï¬elds is obviously relevant to the origin of neutron
star magnetic ï¬elds as well. It still remains to be explained what
shapes the distribution of magnetic ï¬elds among young pulsars, and
why some neutron stars are born as magnetars with extraordinarily
strong dipole ï¬elds of up to 10

G (Olausen & Kaspi 2014; Tau-
ris et al. 2015; Kaspi & Beloborodov 2017; Enoto et al. 2019). Are
these strong ï¬elds of fossil origin (Ferrario & Wickramasinghe 2005;
Ferrario et al. 2009; Schneider et al. 2020) or generated by dynamo
action during or after the supernova (Duncan & Thompson 1992;
Thompson & Duncan 1993)? Naturally, 3D MHD simulations of the
late burning stages cannot comprehensively answer all of these ques-
tions. In order to connect to observable magnetic ï¬elds of neutron
stars, an integrated approach is required that combines stellar evolu-

tion over secular time scales, 3D stellar hydrodynamics, supernova
modelling, and local simulations, and also addresses aspects like ï¬eld
burial (ViganÃ² et al. 2013; Torres-FornÃ© et al. 2016) and the long-
time evolution of magnetic ï¬elds (Aguilera et al. 2008; De Grandis
et al. 2020). Signiï¬cant obstacles need to be overcome until one can
construct a pipeline from 3D progenitor models to 3D supernova sim-
ulations and beyond. However, 3D MHD simulations of convective
burning can already address meaningful questions despite the com-
plexity of the overall problem. As in the purely hydrodynamic case,
the ï¬rst step must be to understand the principles governing mag-
netohydrodynamic convection during the late burning stages based
on somewhat idealised simulations that are broadly representative of
the conditions in convective cores and shells of massive stars.

In this study, we present a ï¬rst simulation of magnetoconvection
during the ï¬nal phase of oxygen shell burning using the ideal MHD
approximation. In the tradition of semi-idealised models of late-stage
convection, we use a setup that falls within the typical range of con-
ditions in the interiors of massive stars in terms of convective Mach
number and shell geometry (for an overview see Collins et al. 2018)
and is not designed as a fully self-consistent model of any one partic-
ular star. This simulation constitutes a ï¬rst step beyond eï¬€ective 1D
prescriptions in stellar evolution models to predict the magnetic ï¬eld
strength and geometry encountered in the inner shells of massive stars
at the pre-supernova stage. We also compare to a corresponding non-
magnetic model of oxygen shell convection to gauge the feedback
of magnetic ï¬elds on the convective ï¬‚ow with a particular view to
two important issues. First, the eï¬ƒciency of the â€œperturbation-aidedâ€
neutrino-driven mechanism depends critically on the magnitude of
the convective velocities during shell burning, and it is important
to determine whether magnetic ï¬elds can signiï¬cantly slow down
convective motions as suggested by some recent simulations of solar
convection (Hotta et al. 2015). Second, magnetic ï¬elds could quanti-
tatively or qualitatively aï¬€ect shell growth by turbulent entrainment,
which has been consistently seen in all recent 3D hydrodynamics
simulations of late-stage convection in massive stars.

Our paper is structured as follows. In Section 2, we describe the
numerical methods, progenitor model, and initial conditions used in
our study and discuss the potential role of non-ideal eï¬€ects . The
results of the simulations are presented in Section 3. We ï¬rst focus
on the strength and geometry of the emerging magnetic ï¬eld and then
analyse the impact of magnetic ï¬elds on the ï¬‚ow, and in particular
on entrainment at shell boundaries. We summarize our results and
discuss their implications in Section 4.

We simulate oxygen and neon shell burning with and without mag-
netic ï¬elds in a non-rotating 18

solar-metallicity star calculated
using the stellar evolution code Kepler (Weaver et al. 1978; Woosley
et al. 2002; Heger & Woosley 2010). The same progenitor model has
previously been used in the shell convection simulation of MÃ¼ller
et al. (2016). The structure of the stellar evolution model at the time
of mapping to 3D is illustrated in Figure 1. The model contains
two active convective shells with suï¬ƒciently short turnover times to
make time-explicit simulations feasible. The oxygen shell extends
from 1

900 km in radius, immediately followed further out by the neon
shell out to 3

For our 3D simulations we employ the Newtonian magnetohy-
drodynamic (MHD) version of the CoCoNuT code as described
in MÃ¼ller & Varma (2020). The MHD equations are solved in

This system conserves the volume integral of a modiï¬ed total energy
density Ë†
, which also contains the cleaning ï¬eld Ë†

is the mass-speciï¬c internal energy. Note that the energy
equation diï¬€ers from that in Tricco et al. (2016) because we imple-
ment divergence cleaninng on a Eulerian grid and do not advect

with the ï¬‚ow unlike in their smoothed particle hydrodynamics ap-
proach. If translated to the Eulerian form of the MHD equations, the
approach of Tricco et al. (2016) would give rise to an extra advection
term in the evolution equation for

, which then requires an addi-
tional term in the energy equation to ensure energy conservation. In
our Eulerian approach, these extra terms are not needed.

Viscosity and resistivity are not included explicitly in the ideal
MHD approximation, and only enter through the discretisation of the
MHD equations, speciï¬cally the spatial reconstruction, the computa-
tion of the Riemann ï¬‚uxes, and the update of the conserved quantities
in the case of reconstruct-solve-average schemes.

While this â€œim-
plicit large-eddy simulationâ€ (ILES) approach is well-established for
hydrodynamic turbulence (Grinstein et al. 2007), the magnetohy-
drodynamic case is more complicated because the behaviour in the
relevant astrophysical regime of low (kinematic) viscosity
may still depend on the magnetic Prandtl number Pm

.
Diï¬€erent from the regime later encountered in the supernova core
where Pm

1, oxygen shell burning is characterised by magnetic
Prandtl numbers slightly below unity (Pm

2). With an eï¬€ective
Prandtl number of Pm

1 in the ILES approach (Federrath et al.
2011), there is a potential concern that spurious small-scale dynamo
ampliï¬cation might arise due to the overestimation of the magnetic
Prandtl number, or that saturation ï¬eld strengths might be too high.
The debate about the magnetic Prandtl number dependence in MHD
turbulence is ongoing with insights from theory and simulations
(e.g., Schekochihin et al. 2004, 2007; Iskakov et al. 2007; Branden-
burg 2011; Pietarila Graham et al. 2010; Sahoo et al. 2011; Thaler &
Spruit 2015; Seshasayanan et al. 2017), astrophysical observations
(e.g., Christensen et al. 2009), and laboratory experiments (PÃ©trÃ©lis
et al. 2007; Monchaux et al. 2007). There is, at the very least, the pos-
sibility of robust small-scale dynamo action and saturation governed
by balance between the inertial terms and Lorentz force terms down
to the low values of Pm

(PÃ©trÃ©lis et al. 2007; Monchaux et al. 2007), provided that both the hy-
drodynamic and magnetic Reynolds number are suï¬ƒciently high. An
ILES approach that places the simulation into a â€œuniversalâ€, strongly
magnetised regime (Beresnyak 2019) thus appears plausible. More-
over, even if the ILES approach were only to provide upper limits for
magnetic ï¬elds and their eï¬€ects on the ï¬‚ow, meaningful conclusions
can still be drawn in the context of shell convection simulations.

For an attempt to quantify the numerical diï¬€usivities, see, e.g., Rembi-
asz et al. (2017). One should emphasise, however, that that the concepts of
numerical and physical viscosity/resistivity must be carefully distinguished.
For one thing, the numerical viscosity and resistivity are problem-dependent
as stressed by Rembiasz et al. (2017). In the case of higher-order recon-
struction schemes, they are also scale-dependent (and hence more akin to
higher-order hyperdiï¬€usivities), and they are aï¬€ected by discrete switches in
the reconstruction scheme and Riemann solver. Because of these subtleties,
the determination of the eï¬€ective (magnetic) Reynolds number of a simulation
is non-trivial (see Section 2.1.2 of MÃ¼ller 2020).

The nuclear source terms are calculated with the 19-species nu-
clear reaction network of Weaver et al. (1978). Neutrino cooling is
ignored, since it becomes subdominant in the late pre-collapse phase
as the contraction of the shells speeds up nuclear burning.
The simulations are conducted on a grid with 400

. To reduce computational
costs, we excise the non-convective inner core up to 3000 km and
replace the excised core with a point mass. The grid extends to a
radius of 50

000 km and includes a small part of the silicon shell, the
entire convective oxygen and neon shells, the non-convective carbon
shell, and parts of the helium shell. Simulations that include the entire
iron core and silicon shell are of course desirable in future, but the
treatment of nuclear quasi-equilibrium in these regions is delicate and
motivates simulations in a shellular domain instead, with a suï¬ƒcient
â€œbuï¬€erâ€ region between the convectively active shells and the inner
boundary of the grid. Due to the signiï¬cant buoyancy jump between
the silicon shell and the oxygen shell, the ï¬‚ow in the convective shell
is largely decoupled from that in the non-convective buï¬€er region.
Hydrodynamic waves excited at the convective boundary and AlfvÃ©n

waves along ï¬eld lines threading both regions can introduce some
coupling, but these are excited by the active convective shell and not
in the convectively quiet buï¬€er region. No physical ï¬‚ux of waves

the oxygen region from below is expected. Moreover, there is
no strong excitation of waves at the convective boundary in the ï¬rst
place because of the low convective Mach number of the ï¬‚ow. It
turns out that coupling by AlfvÃ©n waves can be neglected even more
safely than coupling by internal gravity waves because of the AlfvÃ©n
number of the ï¬‚ow; as we shall see the AlfvÃ©n number always stays
well below unity.

In order to investigate the impact of magnetic ï¬elds on late-
stage oxygen shell convection, we run a purely hydrodynamic, non-
magnetic simulation and an MHD simulation. In the MHD simu-
lation, we impose a homogeneous magnetic ï¬eld with

G
parallel to the grid axis as initial conditions. We implement reï¬‚ect-
ing and periodic boundary conditions in

, respectively. For
the hydrodynamic variables we use hydrostatic extrapolation (MÃ¼ller
2020) at the inner and outer boundary, and impose strictly vanish-
ing advective ï¬‚uxes at the inner boundary. Diï¬€erent from MÃ¼ller
et al. (2016), we do

contract the inner boundary to follow the
contraction and collapse of the core. This means that our models
will not (and are not intended to) provide an accurate representa-
tion of the pre-collapse state of the particular 18

star that we
are simulating. We would expect, e.g., that for the particular 18

model, the burning rate and hence the convective velocities would
increase until the onset of collapse (MÃ¼ller et al. 2016) due to the
contraction of the convective oxygen shell. As a consequence of ac-
celerating convection and ï¬‚ux compression, the magnetic ï¬elds will
likely also be somewhat higher at the onset of collapse. The model
is rather meant to reveal the physical principles governing late-stage
magnetoconvection in massive stars, and to be

of the
typical conditions in oxygen burning shells with the understanding
that there are signiï¬cant variations in convective Mach number and
shell geometry at the onset of collapse (Collins et al. 2018), which
will also be reï¬‚ected in the magnetic ï¬eld strengths in the interiors
of supernova progenitors.

The inner and outer boundary conditions for the magnetic ï¬elds
are less trivial. In simulations of magnetoconvection in the Sun,
various choices such as vertical boundary conditions (

0), vanishing tangential
electric ï¬elds or currents, perfect-conductor boundary conditions,
or extrapolation to a potential solution have been employed (e.g.,
Evolution of the volume-averaged (solid) and maximum (dashed)
magnetic ï¬eld strength within the oxygen shell.

Thelen & Cattaneo 2000; Rempel 2014; KÃ¤pylÃ¤ et al. 2020). Since
our domain boundaries are separated from the convective regions
by shell interfaces with signiï¬cant buoyancy jumps, we opt for the
simplest choice of boundary conditions and merely ï¬x the magnetic
ï¬elds in the ghost zones to their initial values for a homogeneous
vertical magnetic ï¬eld. We argue that due to the buï¬€er regions at
our radial boundaries, and the lack of rotational shear, our choice of
magnetic boundary conditions should not have a signiï¬cant impact
on the dynamically relevant regions of the star.

Both the magnetised and non-magnetised model were run for over 12
minutes of physical time, which corresponds to about 17 convective
turnover times. Very soon after convection develops in the oxygen
shell, the turbulent convective ï¬‚ow starts to rapidly amplify the mag-
netic ï¬elds in this region. To illustrate the growth of the magnetic ï¬eld
we show the root-mean-square (RMS) average and maximum value
of the magnetic ï¬eld in the oxygen shell in Figure 2.The magnetic

G, is ampliï¬ed by over two orders
of magnitude to over 10

G on average within the shell due to con-
vective and turbulent motions. The average magnetic ï¬eld strength
in the shell is still increasing at the end of the simulation, but the
growth rate has slowed down, likely indicating that the model is ap-
proaching some level of magnetic ï¬eld saturation. While we cannot
with certainty extrapolate the growth dynamics without simulating
longer, it appears likely that RMS saturation ï¬eld strength will settle
somewhere around

A closer look reveals that the magnetic ï¬eld is not ampliï¬ed ho-
mogeneously throughout the convective region. The convective ed-
dies push the magnetic ï¬eld lines against the convective boundaries,
where the ï¬elds are then more strongly ampliï¬ed by shear ï¬‚ows. This
is visualised in Figures 3a and 3b, where both magnetic pressure and
magnetic ï¬eld strengths appear concentrated at the convective bound-
ary. The maximum magnetic ï¬eld strength shown in Figure 2 (dashed
line) therefore essentially mirrors the ï¬eld at the inner boundary of
the oxygen shell (not to be confused with the inner grid boundary).

ary at the beginning of the simulation between 20

convective ï¬‚ow is fully developed. The rate of growth of the max-
imum magnetic ï¬eld strength after this increases at approximately
the same rate as the average magnetic ï¬eld strength.

7. Simulations of ï¬eld
ampliï¬cation by a small-scale dynamo in isotropic turbulence often
exhibit a Kazantsev spectrum with power-law index

on large

speak, indicating that ï¬eld ampliï¬cation is subtly diï¬€erent from the

This is borne out by a closer look at the magnetic ï¬eld distribu-
tion within the convective region. Somewhat similar to our recent
simulation of ï¬eld ampliï¬cation by neutrino-driven convection in
core-collapse supernovae (MÃ¼ller & Varma 2020), ï¬eld ampliï¬ca-
tion does not happen homogeneously throughout the convective re-

gion and appears to be predominantly driven by shear ï¬‚ows at the
convective boundaries. To illustrate this, we compare the spherically-
averaged diagonal components of the kinetic (Reynolds) and mag-
netic (Maxwell) stress tensors

At the outer boundaries of the oxygen and neon shell, we ob-

suggests that this â€œpartial equipartitionâ€ may de-

at the inner boundary with

argues against this. It
is plausible, though, that the saturation ï¬eld strength is (or rather will
be) determined at the boundary. Linear stability analysis of the mag-
netised Kelvin-Helmholtz instability (e.g. Chandrasekhar 1961; Sen
1963; Fejer 1964; Miura & Pritchett 1982; Frank et al. 1996; Kep-
pens et al. 1999; Ryu et al. 2000; Obergaulinger, M. et al. 2010; Liu
et al. 2018) shows that shear instability, which is critical for eï¬ƒciently
generating small-scale ï¬elds, are suppressed by magnetic ï¬elds par-
allel to the direction of the shear ï¬‚ow as long as the AlfvÃ©n number
is smaller than two. With kinetic ï¬elds well below equipartition
(cp. Figure 6), our models fall into the regime of low AlfvÃ©n number;
hence the generation of non-radial ï¬elds at the boundaries may be
self-limiting as a result of the stabilising impact of magnetic ï¬elds on
the Kelvin-Helmholtz instability. A naive application of the principle
of marginal stability would suggest saturation occurs once the AlfvÃ©n
velocity at the boundary equals the shear velocity jump across the
shell interface, which would imply

. Our
simulation suggests that saturation probably occurs at signiï¬cantly
smaller values, and a more quantitative analysis of the saturation
mechanism will clearly be required in future to elucidate the relation
between the shear velocity (and possibly the width of the shear layer)
and the saturation ï¬eld strength.
3.2 Impact of Magnetic Fields on Convective Boundary Mixing

The slowing growth of the magnetic ï¬eld indicates that feedback
eï¬€ects on the ï¬‚ow should become important during the later phase
of the simulation. It is particularly interesting to consider the eï¬€ect
of the strong ï¬elds tangential to the oxygen-neon shell interface
on convective boundary mixing, though we also consider potential
eï¬€ects on the ï¬‚ow in the interior of the convective regions.

To this end, we compare the MHD model to a purely hydrodynamic

2016). Ultimately, the high ratio

Since the only diï¬€erence in the setup of the two runs is the presence

purely stochastic. Closer examination suggests that feedback of the

nature of this feedback will become more apparent as we analyse

Figure 8 (panels a and b), the oxygen shell in the non-magnetic model
grows slightly, but perceptibly faster without magnetic ï¬elds than in
the MHD model, starting at a simulation time of about 300 s. The
presence of relatively strong magnetic ï¬elds in the boundary layer
apparently reduces entrainment in line with the inhibiting eï¬€ect of
magnetic ï¬elds parallel to the ï¬‚ow on shear instabilities discussed in
Section 3.1.

occur at around

It appears that the stabilisation of the boundary by magnetic ï¬elds
mostly suppresses rarer, but more powerful entrainment events that
mix bigger lumps of material into the oxygen shell. A comparison
with the shell burning simulations of MÃ¼ller et al. (2016) provides
conï¬dence that this eï¬€ect is robust. Because MÃ¼ller et al. (2016)
contract the inner boundary condition, convection grows more vig-
orous with time and their entrainment rates are higher, adding about
0

to the oxygen shell within 300 s. Their resolution test (Fig-

in the entrained mass between diï¬€erent runs of the same progeni-
tor model. In our simulations, the oxygen shell only grows by about
0

from 300 s to 700 s (i.e, when the magnetic ï¬eld does not

of about 0
between the magnetic and non-magnetic model. It
therefore seems likely that there is indeed an appreciable systematic

eï¬€ect of magnetic ï¬elds on entrainment. Our simulations qualita-
tively illustrate such an eï¬€ect, but models at higher resolution are
of course desirable to more reliably quantify the impact of magnetic
ï¬elds on turbulent entrainment. The resolution requirements for ac-
curate entrainment rates are hard to quantify. Findings from extant
numerical studies of the magnetised Kelvin-Helmholtz instability
(e.g., Keppens et al. 1999) cannot be easily transferred because of
important physical diï¬€erences (e.g., the lack of buoyant stabilisation
of the boundary). In purely hydrodynamic simulations of entrain-

ment during oxygen shell burning, resolving the shear layer between
the oxygen and neon shell with

22 radial zones as in our model
was found to be suï¬ƒcient for quantitatively credible, but not fully
converged results (MÃ¼ller et al. 2016).

The diï¬€erent entrainment rate also explains long-term, time-
averaged diï¬€erences in convective kinetic energy between the two
simulations. The convective kinetic energy is determined by the total
nuclear energy generation rate, which is shown in Figure 8d. Both
models show an overall trend downwards over time in nuclear energy
generation, which can be ascribed to a slight thermal expansion of the
shell and the depletion of fuel. After about 200 s, the purely hydrody-
namics model exhibits a higher energy generation rate, which persists
until the end of the simulations and becomes more pronounced. The
higher energy generation rate in the non-magnetic model is indeed
mirrored by a stronger decrease in the neon mass on the grid (Fig-
ure 9) of about the right amount to explain the average diï¬€erence in
energy generation rate at late times. We note, however, that the strong
episodic entrainment events in the purely hydrodynamic model are

by the inhibiting eï¬€ect of non-radial magnetic ï¬elds on shear insta-
bilities at shell boundaries, which appear to be the primary driver of
ï¬eld ampliï¬cation.

We ï¬nd that magnetic ï¬elds do not have an appreciable eï¬€ect
on the interior ï¬‚ow inside the oxygen shell, but observe a moderate
reduction of turbulent entrainment at the oxygen-neon shell bound-
ary in the presence of magnetic ï¬elds. Magnetic ï¬elds appear to
suppress stronger episodic entrainment events, although they do not
quench entrainment completely. Through the reduced entrainment
rate, magnetic ï¬elds also indirectly aï¬€ect the dynamics inside the
convective region slightly because they reduce the energy release
through the dissociation of ingested neon, which results in slightly
smaller convective velocities in the MHD model.

Our ï¬ndings have important implications for core-collapse su-
pernova modelling. We predict initial ï¬elds in the oxygen shell of
non-rotating progenitors that are signiï¬cantly stronger than assumed
in our recent simulation of a neutrino-driven explosion aided by
dynamo-generated magnetic ï¬elds (MÃ¼ller & Varma 2020). With rel-
atively strong seed-ï¬elds, there is likely less of a delay until magnetic
ï¬elds can contribute the additional â€œboostâ€ to neutrino heating and

purely hydrodynamic instabilities seen in MÃ¼ller & Varma (2020).
This should further contribute to the robustness of the neutrino-
driven mechanism for non-rotating and slowly-rotating massive stars.
Our simulations also suggest that the perturbation-aided mechanism
(Couch & Ott 2013; MÃ¼ller & Janka 2015) will not be substantially
aï¬€ected by the inclusion of magnetic ï¬elds. Since magnetic ï¬elds do
not become strong enough to substantially alter the bulk ï¬‚ow inside
the convective region, the convective velocities and eddy scales as
the key parameters for perturbation-aided explosions remain largely
unchanged.

The implications of our results for neutron star magnetic ï¬elds
are more diï¬ƒcult to evaluate since the observable ï¬elds will, to a
large degree, be set by processes during and after the supernova and
cannot be simply extrapolated from the progenitor stage by magnetic
ï¬‚ux conservation. That said, dipole ï¬elds of order 10

G at the base
of the oxygen shell â€“ which is likely to end up as the neutron star
surface region â€“ are not in overt conï¬‚ict with dipole ï¬elds of order
10

G in many young pulsars inside supernova remnants (Enoto
et al. 2019). However, considering the relatively strong small-scale
ï¬elds of

G, it may prove diï¬ƒ-
cult to produce neutron stars without strong small-scale ï¬elds at the
surface. There is a clear need for an integrated approach towards the
evolution of magnetic ï¬elds from the progenitor phase through the
supernova and into the compact remnant phase in order to fully grasp
the implications of the current simulations.

Evidently, further follow-up studies are also needed on the ï¬nal
evolutionary phases of supernova progenitors. Longer simulations
and resolution studies will be required to better address issues like
the saturation ï¬eld strength, the saturation mechanism, and the impact
of magnetic ï¬elds on turbulent entrainment. Full models that include
the core and self-consistently follow the evolution of the star to
collapse will be required to generate accurate 3D initial conditions
for supernova simulations. The critical issue of non-ideal eï¬€ects and
the behaviour of turbulent magnetoconvection for magnetic Prandtl
numbers slightly smaller than one at very high Reynolds numbers
deserves particular consideration. Some ï¬ndings of our â€œoptimisticâ€
approach based on the ideal MHD approximation should, however,
prove robust, such as the modest eï¬€ect of magnetic ï¬elds on the
convective bulk ï¬‚ow and hence the reliability of purely hydrodynamic
models (Couch et al. 2015; MÃ¼ller et al. 2016; Yadav et al. 2020;
MÃ¼ller 2020; Fields & Couch 2020) and even 1D mixing-length
theory (Collins et al. 2018) to predict pre-collapse perturbations
Total mass of neon in the entire computational domain for the
purely hydrodynamic simulation (purple) and the MHD simulation (black).

associated with an immediate increase in nuclear energy gen-
eration rate. This is mainly because the energy release from the
dissociation of the entrained neon is delayed and spread out in time
as the entrained material is diluted and eventually mixed down to
regions of suï¬ƒciently high temperature.

The overall eï¬€ect of magnetic ï¬elds on the bulk ï¬‚ow is rather
modest. We do not see a similarly strong quenching of the convective
ï¬‚ow by magnetic ï¬elds as in recent MHD simulations of the solar
convection zone (Hotta et al. 2015), who reported a reduction of
convective velocities by up to 50% at the base of the convection zone.
Such an eï¬€ect is not expected as long as the magnetic ï¬elds stay well
below kinetic equipartition in the interior of convective shells as in
our MHD simulation. Longer simulations will be required to conï¬rm
that magnetic ï¬elds during late shell burning stages indeed remain
â€œweakâ€ by comparison and do not appreciably inï¬‚uence the bulk
dynamics of convection.

We investigated the ampliï¬cation and saturation of magnetic ï¬elds
during convective oxygen shell burning and the backreaction of the

ï¬eld on the convective ï¬‚ow by conducting a 3D MHD simulation and
a purely hydrodynamic simulation of an 18

progenitor shortly be-
fore core collapse. The simulations were run for about 12 minutes of
physical time (corresponding to about 17 convective turnover times),
at which point ï¬eld ampliï¬cation has slowed down considerably,
though a quasi-stationary state has not yet been fully established.
The magnetic ï¬eld in the oxygen shell is ampliï¬ed to

G
and dominated by small-to-medium-scale structures with angular
wavenumber

7. The dipole component is considerably smaller
with

G near the inner boundary of the oxygen shell and less fur-
ther outside. The proï¬les of the radial and non-radial diagonal com-
ponents

of the Maxwell stress tensor mirror
the corresponding components

of the Reynolds
stress tensor, but remain about an order of magnitude smaller, i.e.,
kinetic equipartition is not reached. However,

proach or exceed the radial component

at the convective bound-
aries. The saturation mechanism for ï¬eld ampliï¬cation needs to be
studied in more detail, but we speculate that saturation is mediated

in supernova progenitors. Future 3D simulations will also have to
address rotation and its interplay with convection and magnetic ï¬elds.
